definitions.definition: to rub something against a surface, in order to remove dirt or liquid from it; to rub a surface with a cloth, etc. in order to clean it
definitions.sensetop: wipe something (on something)wipe something with somethingwipe something + adj.

examples.text: Please wipe your feet on the mat.
He wiped his hands on a clean towel.
She was sniffing and wiping her eyes with a tissue.
He wiped his plate clean with a piece of bread.
The plastic surface can be easily wiped.
When you've finished with it, simply wipe it clean with a damp cloth.

definitions.definition: to remove dirt, liquid, etc. from something by using a cloth, your hand, etc.

examples.text: He wiped the sweat from his forehead.
Use that cloth to wipe up the mess.
She gently wiped the tears from her eyes.
I wiped up the spilled wine.
He wiped the marks off the wall.
He paused to wipe the sweat from his forehead.

definitions.definition: to remove information, sound, images, etc. from a computer, video, etc.

examples.text: You must have wiped off that programme I recorded.
Somebody had wiped all the tapes.

definitions.definition: to deliberately forget an experience because it was unpleasant or embarrassing
definitions.sensetop: wipe something from somethingwipe something out

examples.text: I tried to wipe the whole episode from my mind.
You can never wipe out the past.

definitions.definition: to defeat somebody completely in an argument or a competition
to stop smiling, especially because somebody else is annoyed and does not think the situation is funny

examples.text: Wipe that grin off your face and get back to work.
Wipe that stupid smile off your face.

definitions.definition: to destroy or remove somebody/something completely
to agree to forget about past mistakes or arguments and start again with a relationship

wordOrigin: Old English wīpian, of Germanic origin; related to whip.
